cellularAutomata.cellState.model
Class CellState

java.lang.Object
  cellularAutomata.cellState.model.CellState
Direct Known Subclasses:
ComplexState, ComplexValuedVectorState, IntegerCellState, IntegerVectorState, ObjectState, RealValuedState, RealValuedVectorState
public abstract class CellState
extends java.lang.Object

Holds the state for a cell in a cellular automaton. The state may be a binary number, n-nary number, vectors of binary numbers, colors, or anything else. The state may also hold multiple unrelated values. For example, some lattice gasses need to indicate (1) a vector value, and (2) whether or not the cell is on the interior or boundary of the grid.

Also, any necessary instance variables that are set through a constructor must be static. That way, they can be set once by reflection.

To save space, the view is static. This means that all child classes should only allow constructors that include the view as a parameter. Otherwise, two different constructors might get called with different views and cause different display results (especially when drawing with the mouse).

Author:
David Bahr

Method Detail

resetWarnings

public static void resetWarnings()
Warnings are issued only once per instantiation of a simulation, but this allows the warnings to be reset.

clone

public abstract CellState clone()
Creates a clone of this cellState; this method must return a different instance of the cell state, but with all the same values.

The intent is that, for any CellState x, the expression: x.clone() != x will be true, and that the expression: x.clone().getClass() == x.getClass() will be true. Also: x.clone().equals(x) will be true.

(Note this method is used in places where we need a copy of the cell's state but that the same instance would cause unpredictable or incorrect behavior.)

Overrides:
clone in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
A unique copy of the cell's state (must not return "this" object).

equals

public boolean equals(CellState state)
Tests if the value of two cell states are equal.

Returns:
true if the cell states have the same value.

Returns:
The list of all objects that tagged this cell's state. May be null.

Gets the object that tagged the cell's state (usually an analysis or analyses).

The object that tagged the cell's state. May be null.

getValue

public java.lang.Object getValue()
Gets the state of the cell.

Returns:
Returns the current state of the cell.

isAlternate

public abstract boolean isAlternate()
Tests if a given CellState is "alternate". The meaning of "alternate state" may change for different cellular automatons, so this method must be implemented by the child class. Typically "alternate" means a cell has a different value other than "full" or "blank", but binary CellStates may just assign the "full" or "blank" value to the alternate state.

Returns:
true if the state is alternate (typically, other than "full" or "blank").
See Also:
setToAlternateState()

isEmpty

public abstract boolean isEmpty()
Tests if a given CellState is "empty" or "blank". The meaning of "empty state" may change for different cellular automatons, so this method must be implemented by the child class. Typically "empty" means an unoccupied site (for example, a 0) versus "full" which means an occupied site (for example, a 1).

Returns:
true if the state is empty.
See Also:
setToEmptyState()

isDrawState

public boolean isDrawState()
Tests if a given CellState is the "drawing" state, in other words the state that can be drawn on the screen by a user with a left click. Called by LatticeMouseListener when the user draws a cell with a left click. By default this tests for the full state. May be overridden in child classes for different behaviors. For example, in IntegerCellState, the drawing state is set to a color specified by the user (from a color chooser), so it tests for that color/state.

Returns:
true if the state is the drawing state.

isFull

public abstract boolean isFull()
Tests if a given CellState is "full". The meaning of "full state" may change for different cellular automatons, so this method must be implemented by the child class. Typically "full" means an occupied site (for example, a 1) versus "empty" which means an unoccupied site (for example, a 0).

Returns:
true if the state is full.
See Also:
setToFullState()

isTagged

public boolean isTagged()
True when the state has been tagged for extra visibility.

Returns:
true if the state is tagged for extra visibility.

setTagged

public void setTagged(boolean tagged,
                      java.lang.Object taggingObject)
When set to true, the cell state will be tagged for special purposes (such as an extra-visible display, or keeping track of the cell in an analysis). For example, the CellStateView may opt to display this cell's state in bright red rather than a normal color. The CellStateView is not obligated to display tagged states in any special color, but usually will. A unique tagged color is reserved for the specified taggingObject.

Parameters:
tagged - true if the cell should be tagged for special purposes such as extra-visible display.
taggingObject - The object that is doing the tagging.

setToAlternateState

public abstract void setToAlternateState()
Sets an alternate state for this cell state. Useful for creating walls, obstacles, or other states besides the standard "full" or "blank". If no special state is desired, then recommended that the implementation call setFullState().

setToEmptyState

public abstract void setToEmptyState()
Sets an "empty", "blank", "minimum", or "off" value for this cell state. This may be a 0 (for binary states), a minimum value integer, a minimum length vector, or anything else appropriate to this particular class.

setToDrawingState

public void setToDrawingState()
Sets the state to the one that is specified as a "drawing state". Called by LatticeMouseListener when the user draws a cell with a left click. By default is set to the full state. May be overridden in child classes for different behaviors. For example, in IntegerCellState, the drawing state is set to a color specified by the user (from a color chooser).

setToFullState

public abstract void setToFullState()
Sets a "full", "maximum", or "on" value for this cell state. This may be a 1 (for binary states), a maximum value integer, a maximum length vector, or anything else appropriate to this particular class.

setToRandomState

public abstract void setToRandomState(double probability)
Sets a random value for this cell state. This may be a random bit, a random length length vector in a random direction, or anything else appropriate to this particular class.

Parameters:
probability - The probability that the cell will be occupied rather than blank.

setStateFromString

public abstract void setStateFromString(java.lang.String state)
Sets a value for this cell state by parsing a string. This may parse a Bit, an Integer, a vector of numbers or anything else appropriate to this state. By contract, this method should call setValue() from this class before exiting.

setValue

public void setValue(java.lang.Object stateValue)
Sets a value for this cell state.

Parameters:
stateValue - The new state of the cell.

toInt

public abstract int toInt()
The integer value of the state if it exists, and otherwise the hashcode of the object. It is up to the subclass to decide which is most appropriate. Most cellular automata have states that represent a finite alphabet of integers (usually 0 and 1).

Returns:
The state as an int.

toString

public java.lang.String toString()
The state evaluated as a string.

Overrides:
toString in class java.lang.Object
Returns:
the state as a string.
